title: David Walliams Removed from Children's Book Festival Amid Allegations
summary: David Walliams, a prominent British author and comedian known for his children's books, has been removed from the Waterstones Children's Book Festival scheduled for next year. This decision follows allegations of inappropriate behaviour towards young women, which Walliams strongly denies. His publisher, HarperCollins, recently severed ties with him, adding to the controversy. The festival, organized by the Waterstones book chain, will take place in three locations: Dundee, Lincoln, and Taunton. Walliams has been taken off the speakers list, with other authors like Cressida Cowell and Liz Pichon still set to appear. Walliams is a highly successful author, having sold over 60 million books worldwide, with titles such as Gangsta Granny and The Boy in the Dress adapted into TV films. He is seeking legal advice to contest the allegations, claiming he was not informed or given a chance to respond. The BBC has stated it has no future projects with him, though his scheduled TV appearance on Boxing Day remains unchanged. This situation highlights issues of accountability and reputation in the publishing industry.

background_read: David Walliams is a multi-talented British figure known as a comedian, TV personality, and bestselling children's author. He began his writing career with The Boy in the Dress in 2008, published by HarperCollins, and has since authored over 40 books, including popular series like Gangsta Granny and Billionaire Boy. His works have been translated into 55 languages and adapted into successful TV films, contributing to his global sales of over 60 million copies. The Waterstones Children's Book Festival is an annual event that promotes literacy and brings authors and young readers together across the UK. Allegations of misconduct in the entertainment and publishing industries have become a significant topic in recent years, leading to increased scrutiny and actions like severing ties with accused individuals. This case raises questions about due process, as Walliams claims he was not informed of the allegations or given a chance to defend himself, highlighting tensions between protecting individuals and ensuring safe environments.
